semantic_title: Coding Guidelines for Transplant Complications Other Than Kidney
section_path: Section I > C. Chapter-Specific Coding Guidelines > 19. Chapter 19: Injury, poisoning, and certain other consequences of external causes > g. Complications of care > 3) Transplant complications > (a) Transplant complications other than kidney

content.full_text: Codes under category T86, Complications of transplanted organs and tissues, are for use for both complications and rejection of transplanted organs. A transplant complication code is only assigned if the complication affects the function of the transplanted organ. Two codes are required to fully describe a transplant complication: the appropriate code from category T86 and a secondary code that identifies the complication. Pre-existing conditions or conditions that develop after the transplant are not coded as complications unless they affect the function of the transplanted organs. See I.C.21. for transplant organ removal status See I.C.2. for malignant neoplasm associated with transplanted organ. See I.C.1.d.4. for sequencing of sepsis due to infection in transplanted organ (Evidence: pg no: 86, L47-L51)
content.summary: Transplant complications use T86 codes only when organ function is affected, requiring two codes: T86 code plus complication-specific code (Evidence: pg no: 86, L47-L51)
key_concepts: T86 category usage (Evidence: pg no: 86, L47-L48)
Pre-existing condition exclusion (Evidence: pg no: 86, L50-L51)

detailed_rules.rule_text: A transplant complication code is only assigned if the complication affects the function of the transplanted organ (Evidence: pg no: 86, L48-L49)
detailed_rules.explanation: T86 codes should only be used when complications directly impact the transplanted organ's function, not for unrelated conditions (Evidence: pg no: 86, L48-L49)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Two codes are required to fully describe a transplant complication: the appropriate code from category T86 and a secondary code that identifies the complication (Evidence: pg no: 86, L49-L50)
detailed_rules.explanation: Complete coding of transplant complications requires both the T86 code and a specific code describing the nature of the complication (Evidence: pg no: 86, L49-L50)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Pre-existing conditions or conditions that develop after the transplant are not coded as complications unless they affect the function of the transplanted organs (Evidence: pg no: 86, L50-L51)
detailed_rules.explanation: Only conditions that directly impact transplanted organ function qualify as transplant complications (Evidence: pg no: 86, L50-L51)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Identify complication in transplant patient
Step 2: Determine if complication affects transplanted organ function
Step 3: If yes, assign appropriate T86 code
Step 4: Add secondary code identifying specific complication
Step 5: Consider cross-references for special situations

code_ranges.description: Complications of transplanted organs and tissues (Evidence: pg no: 86, L47-L48)
code_ranges.requirement: Use only when organ function is affected
usage_rules: Only assign if complication affects organ function (Evidence: pg no: 86, L48-L49)
Requires secondary code for specific complication (Evidence: pg no: 86, L49-L50)
Not for pre-existing conditions unless affecting function (Evidence: pg no: 86, L50-L51)

code_patterns.description: Two codes required for transplant complications (Evidence: pg no: 86, L49-L50)
code_patterns.explanation: T86 code plus secondary code describing complication

references_to.title: Transplant organ removal status
references_to.explanation: Referenced for transplant organ removal status coding (Evidence: pg no: 86, L51)

references_to.title: Malignant neoplasm associated with transplanted organ
references_to.explanation: Referenced for cancer in transplant patients (Evidence: pg no: 86, L51)

references_to.title: Sequencing of sepsis due to infection in transplanted organ
references_to.explanation: Referenced for sepsis sequencing in transplant patients (Evidence: pg no: 86, L51)

coding_scenarios.scenario: Heart transplant patient develops acute rejection affecting cardiac function
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Heart transplant patient presents with acute rejection, echocardiogram shows decreased ejection fraction
step_by_step: Step 1: Identify acute rejection in heart transplant patient
Step 2: Confirm rejection affects heart function (decreased EF)
Step 3: Assign T86.21 for heart transplant rejection
Step 4: No additional specific code needed as rejection is specified

correct_coding.rationale: Transplant rejection affects organ function, qualifying for T86 code (Evidence: pg no: 86, L48-L49)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Should use transplant-specific code when rejection affects function
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Using general condition codes instead of transplant-specific codes

coding_scenarios.scenario: Liver transplant patient develops diabetes not affecting liver function
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Liver transplant patient develops new-onset diabetes mellitus, liver function tests normal
step_by_step: Step 1: Identify diabetes in liver transplant patient
Step 2: Determine diabetes does not affect liver function
Step 3: Do not use T86 code
Step 4: Code diabetes as primary condition

correct_coding.sequencing: Diabetes first, transplant status as additional
correct_coding.rationale: Condition not affecting transplant function is not coded as complication (Evidence: pg no: 86, L50-L51)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Should not use T86 when condition doesn't affect organ function
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Using T86 codes for unrelated post-transplant conditions

warnings: Only use T86 codes when complications affect transplanted organ function (Evidence: pg no: 86, L48-L49)
Do not code unrelated conditions as transplant complications (Evidence: pg no: 86, L50-L51)
best_practices: Always use two codes for transplant complications (Evidence: pg no: 86, L49-L50)
Assess whether condition affects organ function before using T86 (Evidence: pg no: 86, L48-L49)
Review cross-references for special situations (Evidence: pg no: 86, L51)
common_mistakes: Using T86 codes for conditions not affecting organ function (Evidence: pg no: 86, L48-L49)
Using only T86 code without secondary complication code (Evidence: pg no: 86, L49-L50)
Coding all post-transplant conditions as complications (Evidence: pg no: 86, L50-L51)
tips: Focus on organ function impact when determining T86 usage (Evidence: pg no: 86, L48-L49)
Consider transplant status codes for unrelated conditions (Evidence: pg no: 86, L50-L51)
implementation_notes: Requires clinical assessment of organ function
May need consultation with transplant team
